Claude Code EAP Report

Opus 4.5 vs Opus 4.6: Behavioral Patterns in Practice

An exploratory single-user case study across 2,320 tasks—observational findings, not controlled comparison
Samuel H. Christie V · February 2026 · Claude Code Early Access Program
AI-assisted analysis: This report was generated with substantial assistance from Claude (Opus 4.6). All statistical computations, table generation, and report assembly are automated, but prose was drafted and reviewed with LLM assistance. Numbers are computed from data; interpretive claims may contain inaccuracies. Additionally, all data comes from a single user’s workflow over a limited time period—treat all findings as anecdotal observations, not generalizable conclusions.

Executive Summary

Per-Task Cost
$2.46 vs $2.62
4.6 saves 10–35% at trivial-moderate; +29% at major (§2)
Output Token Ratio
2.4×
4.6: 2,240 avg vs 4.5: 953 avg
Tool Calls / Task
+53%
Per-task mean 13.4 vs 8.8 (incl. subagents: 16.3 vs 10.4) (§7)
Bonferroni Survivors
93 / 529
93 tests survive across overall and per-complexity strata (including tool calls, tools/file, alignment, duration, completion, communication, autonomy)
Study design note: This is a single-user observational study with non-random task assignment. Opus 4.5 data spans 2 months across 30 projects (1,729 tasks); Opus 4.6 spans 8 days across 14 projects (591 tasks). Differences may reflect the user, project mix, or time period rather than model capabilities. All findings should be treated as hypotheses for future testing.

Observed patterns suggest the two models work differently at comparable success rates. Opus 4.6 uses more tool calls, deploys subagents that are 74% read-only Explore agents, and plans 8× more often. The single largest effect is thinking fraction (d=0.67, §3): 4.6 thinks less often but more deeply, reserving thinking for moderate+ complexity. Of 529 statistical tests with Bonferroni correction, 93 survive—mostly about how each model works (tool usage, distributions), not whether they succeed. The data is consistent with a tentative characterization: Opus 4.5 acts first and adjusts, while Opus 4.6 investigates first and implements in concentrated bursts. The confounded study design means this framing is a hypothesis, not a conclusion. The analysis was iterative—several initial findings were revised or reversed when more direct signals became available (§10).

The report is organized in ten sections: token economics (§2), thinking calibration (§3), behavioral patterns (§4), quality implications (§5–6), resource scaling (§7), session dynamics (§8), model profiles (§9), and methodology (§10).

Contents & Key Findings
  1. Dataset at a Glance463 sessions, 2,320 tasks, 35 projects, $7,411 total cost
  2. Token Economy & Cost4.6 10–35% cheaper trivial–moderate despite 2.4× output
  3. Thinking & Calibrationd=0.67 LARGE effect, #1 of 529 tests
  4. Behavioral Patterns8× planning; 74% read-only Explore; effort front-loading
  5. Quality & SatisfactionAlignment survives Bonferroni; 4.6 fails less (8.5% vs 13.2%)
  6. Edit Accuracy4.6 rewrites 10.3% vs 16.6%
  7. Complexity & Resource UsageTool calls strongest signal (p<0.000003)
  8. Session Dynamics2.2× explore phase; compaction preserves not degrades
  9. Model ProfilesObserved behavioral patterns (not routing recommendations)
  10. Methodology529 tests, sensitivity-validated

1. Dataset at a Glance

Sessions Analyzed

327 (4.5) + 136 (4.6)
Tasks Extracted
2,320
1,729 (4.5) + 591 (4.6)
Projects Spanned

9 shared between both models
Total API Cost
$7,411
$5,292 (4.5) + $2,119 (4.6)

All data comes from a single user's organic Claude Code sessions between December 2025 and February 2026. The dataset is intentionally asymmetric: Opus 4.5 served as the primary model for two months, while Opus 4.6 entered evaluation in early February. This means Opus 4.5 totals are larger in absolute terms, but per-task and per-session comparisons normalize for this. Where sample size limits statistical power, the report notes it explicitly.

The 8-day concentration of the Opus 4.6 data creates a temporal clustering concern: a productive stretch, a particular project focus, or simply the novelty of a new model could color all 591 tasks simultaneously. The report treats tasks as independent observations, but short collection windows make this assumption weaker for 4.6 than for 4.5’s two-month span.

Per-model composition

The dataset reflects organic usage patterns, not a controlled experiment. Opus 4.5 accumulated sessions over two months of daily use; Opus 4.6 entered evaluation in early February 2026.

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6 Combined
Sessions 327 136 463
Tasks 1,729 591 2,320
Tasks / session 5.3 4.3 5.0
Projects 30 14 35
Date range Dec 5 – Feb 10 Feb 3 – Feb 11 Dec 5 – Feb 11
User messages 20,538 10,712 31,250
Tool calls 18,002 9,658 27,660

The 2:1 session ratio means per-task averages for Opus 4.5 are more robust, while Opus 4.6 estimates carry wider confidence intervals. Opus 4.6 sessions are concentrated across 14 projects (all of which also have Opus 4.5 sessions), providing natural overlap for matched-pair comparisons where they apply.

The task type distributions are broadly similar across models, suggesting the user's work patterns remained consistent. The complexity mix is also comparable, though Opus 4.6 has a slightly higher share of moderate-and-above tasks (42.1% vs 33.3%), likely reflecting the evaluation period's focus on substantive work rather than quick queries.

Code output

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6 Combined
Files touched 2,893 1,549 4,442
Lines added 178,794 64,673 243,467
Lines removed 37,493 18,186 55,679

Cache reads dominate the token budget: 91% of all tokens processed were served from cache rather than freshly encoded. This reflects Claude Code's prompt architecture, where the system prompt and conversation history are re-sent with each API call but largely hit the prompt cache.

With the dataset in view, we turn to what the token data reveals about how each model allocates its computational budget.

2. Token Economy & Cost

Opus 4.6 costs 7% more per task on average ($2.62 vs $2.46), despite producing 2.4× more output tokens and making more API round-trips (9.6 vs 7.5 requests/task). But this aggregate masks a complexity-dependent pattern: at trivial through moderate levels, 4.6 is 10–35% cheaper, likely because its session structure yields better within-session prompt caching (cache TTL is 5 minutes). The cost advantage reverses at complex and major tiers, where 4.6’s heavier tool usage outweighs caching gains.

Per-Task Cost
$2.46 vs $2.62
4.6 is 7% more expensive overall; cheaper at trivial–moderate
Output Token Ratio
2.4×
4.6 produces 2,240 vs 953 avg tokens
Per-Request Output
1.8×
233 vs 128 tokens/request

The 2.7× ratio for refactoring is notable: Opus 4.6 produces substantially more output tokens for refactoring tasks, suggesting more thorough changes. For continuation tasks (follow-ups within a session), Opus 4.6 produces 2.2× the output volume of Opus 4.5.

Session-Hour Cost

Normalizing by session hours rather than task count: Opus 4.5 costs $12.75/session-hour ($5,292 over 415.2h) vs $6.81/session-hour for Opus 4.6 ($2,119 over 310.9h). Session hours measure wall-clock time from first to last message, so this metric includes idle time and is not a direct measure of active coding cost.

Cost pattern (with caveats): Despite producing more output and costing 7% more per task overall, Opus 4.6 appears 10–35% cheaper at trivial through moderate complexity, likely from within-session prompt caching (5-minute TTL). The exception is major tasks, where 4.6 costs +29% more—but this is based on 18 4.6 major tasks vs 19 for 4.5, so the estimate is unreliable. These figures come from organic sessions where task mix and session structure differ between models; per-complexity cost advantages should be interpreted cautiously.

Per-request output is the 3rd largest effect size across all 529 tests. Opus 4.6 produces more tokens per API round-trip at every complexity level, concentrating work into fewer, larger responses rather than many small incremental calls.

Cache Efficiency by Complexity

Thinking tokens are billed as output but do not enter the conversation history or affect cache behavior. Visible text output accumulates in history and increases subsequent input size. Cache writes ($18.75/MTok) are 12.5× more expensive than cache reads ($1.50/MTok).

Token breakdown by complexity level

Per-task average token usage driving the cost differences. Opus 4.6 produces more output but uses less fresh input, relying more on cached context:

Complexity 4.5 output/task 4.6 output/task 4.5 thinking chars 4.6 thinking chars 4.5 input/task 4.6 input/task 4.5 requests 4.6 requests
Trivial 97 184 864 811 14 15 1.6 1.8
Simple 514 761 1,717 1,551 137 159 5.7 5.3
Moderate 1,506 2,571 3,775 3,974 601 267 11.4 11.8
Complex 3,903 9,416 7,257 9,150 1,484 490 26.3 29.7
Major 8,465 15,971 11,747 7,199 2,020 477 52.4 66.3

At complex tasks, Opus 4.6 uses fewer fresh input tokens per task (490 vs 1,484) while producing 141% more output (9,416 vs 3,903). Despite using similar request counts per task at the complex level (29.7 vs 26.3), Opus 4.6 achieves much more effective cache utilization, and the output cost premium is offset by input savings.

Caveat: These averages come from organic sessions with different task mixes per model. Some of the per-complexity gap may reflect session-level factors (e.g., caching benefits accumulate within longer sessions).

The cost difference raises a natural question: does 4.6’s different spending pattern correspond to different thinking strategies? The next section examines thinking calibration—the single largest effect in the study.

3. Thinking & Calibration

Thinking Fraction Effect
d=0.67
#1 effect of 529 tests (LARGE)
Thinking Frequency
75% vs 58%
4.5 thinks more often but shallowly
Thinking Depth
+58%
4,175 vs 2,635 chars when thinking

Thinking fraction is the single largest effect in the study (d=0.67, LARGE). Opus 4.5 thinks on 75% of tasks but shallowly; Opus 4.6 thinks on 58% of tasks but more deeply when it does (4,175 vs 2,635 chars). The pattern suggests 4.6 has better calibration of when thinking is needed, reserving it for moderate-and-above complexity.

Thinking calibration: Opus 4.6 shows better calibration of when thinking is needed. It skips thinking for 57% of trivial tasks (vs 23% for Opus 4.5), but engages thinking for 90%+ of moderate-and-above tasks. Opus 4.5 over-thinks easy problems; at moderate complexity, both converge.

Significance: Thinking fraction survives Bonferroni correction across all complexity strata and cross-cut dimensions. This is the most robust and consistent finding in the study.

Thinking calibration is one manifestation of broader behavioral differences between the models. The next section examines other behavioral patterns—subagent deployment, planning adoption, and effort distribution.

4. Behavioral Patterns

Planning Adoption
8×
13.9% vs 1.7% of tasks
Explore Subagents
74% vs 47%
4.6 favors read-only exploration
Autonomy Level
Bonferroni
Distribution survives correction (V=0.15)

Beyond token economics, the models differ in how they approach tasks. Opus 4.6 plans more often (13.9% vs 1.7% of tasks), deploys more subagents, and favors read-only exploration over general-purpose workers. These behavioral differences are among the most visible in the dataset, though the Claude Code platform itself evolved between the two collection periods—some of the shift may reflect SDK changes rather than model decisions.

Subagent strategies diverge: Both models deploy similar total subagents (283 vs 262) but they serve different purposes. For Opus 4.6, 74% are lightweight, read-only Explore agents that gather context before implementation begins, with 15% general-purpose. Opus 4.5 splits its subagents more evenly—47% Explore, 37% general-purpose implementation workers that visibly modify files. Both front-load research, but Opus 4.6 concentrates even more heavily on read-only exploration.
Significance: Autonomy level distribution (p<0.001, Cramér’s V=0.15) survives Bonferroni correction (threshold p<0.0000945).

Planning Adoption

Opus 4.6 enters plan mode on 13.9% of tasks (82 of 591) vs 1.7% for Opus 4.5. Adoption scales steeply with complexity: 51.4% at complex, 72.2% at major. Planned tasks show a modest alignment benefit (+0.18 overall) that diminishes at complex and major tiers.

Effort Distribution

Effort distribution shows Opus 4.6 allocates more tool calls to research (35.1% vs 28.3%) and fewer to implementation (17.5% vs 27.0%), consistent with the research-first approach visible in subagent type preferences.

Different behavioral strategies raise the question of whether they lead to different outcomes. The next section examines completion rates, failure rates, and user satisfaction—the quality signals that the behavioral patterns should ultimately serve.

5. Quality & Satisfaction

Failed Rate
8.5% vs 13.2%
4.6 fails less often (p=0.002)
Alignment Score
d=-0.21
4.6 higher (p=0.000023, Bonferroni)
Quality Survivors
3 of 7
3 of 7 overall Bonferroni survivors are quality metrics

LLM-annotated alignment scores (1–5 scale) show Opus 4.6 scoring higher on average, an effect that survives Bonferroni correction (p=0.000023, d=-0.21). The failed rate difference is also notable: 8.5% of 4.6 tasks fail vs 13.2% for 4.5 (p=0.002, marginal after Bonferroni correction). Both alignment and failure rate are LLM-classified—a Claude Haiku model reads each session transcript and assigns scores. The “LLM quality judgement” approach was abandoned as unreliable (see §10), but alignment scoring proved more robust because it rates user-goal correspondence from observable signals rather than attempting to judge code quality directly.

Two categorical distributions—task completion and communication quality—also survive Bonferroni as chi-square tests, indicating the models differ in how they reach outcomes, not just in outcome rates. Note that the completion distribution test (p=0.000012) survives, while the individual completion rate proportion test (p=0.025) is marginal. All chi-square tests carry a low-expected-cell-count warning due to rare categories in the 20-status taxonomy.

Completion Distribution

OutcomeDistribution (with 95% CI)Δ

A
13.0%

12.0%
 ≈ Tie

Satisfaction trends higher for 4.6 (+5.0pp) but does not survive Bonferroni correction (p=0.018). Dissatisfaction rates are essentially tied (13.0% vs 12.0%, p=0.53). Both completion and sentiment are LLM-classified: a Claude Haiku annotator reads the full session transcript for each task, classifying completion status from a 20-category taxonomy and inferring user sentiment from contextual signals (follow-up messages, tone shifts, task abandonment patterns). These classifications were validated through human spot-checks of flagged cases, but no formal inter-rater reliability was computed.

Quality confound: Opus 4.6’s different complexity mix (42% moderate-and-above vs 33% for 4.5) means it tackles harder work on average. Despite this, it achieves higher alignment scores and a lower failure rate—suggesting genuine capability improvement, though task selection remains confounded. Complexity-stratified alignment scores would strengthen or weaken this claim but are not yet part of the pipeline.

Bonferroni Correction

With 11 independent tests conducted (1 Mann-Whitney U, 9 proportion tests, 1 chi-square), the Bonferroni-corrected significance threshold is Î± = 0.05 / 11 = 0.0045.

Tests surviving Bonferroni correction (p < 0.0045):

  • Alignment score: p = 0.000023 (significant)
  • Task completion distribution: p = 0.000012 (significant)

Tests significant at Î± = 0.05 but not after correction:

  • Satisfaction Rate: p = 0.0120 (marginal)
  • Complete Rate: p = 0.0254 (marginal)
  • Failed Rate: p = 0.0020 (marginal)
  • Scope Expanded Rate: p = 0.0145 (marginal)

Non-significant tests:

  • Dissatisfaction Rate: p = 0.653 (both models 0%)
  • One Shot Rate: p = 0.688
  • Good Execution Rate: p = 0.638
  • Has Edits Rate: p = 0.316
  • Has Overlaps Rate: p = 0.076

Quality metrics paint a consistent-but-modest picture: 4.6 fails less and scores higher on alignment, but effect sizes are small (d=0.21) and the LLM-classification methodology adds a layer of uncertainty. The next section asks whether these quality differences manifest in the editing process itself.

6. Edit Accuracy

Rewrite Rate
10.3% vs 16.6%
4.6 rewrites less of its own output
Editing Tasks
946
700 (4.5) + 246 (4.6)
Overlapping Edits
407 vs 120
Self-corrections, error recovery, user-directed, iterative

Edit timeline analysis tracks every Edit and Write tool call, building per-file content ownership maps to detect when a model later overwrites its own earlier output. Opus 4.5 rewrites 16.6% of its edits vs 10.3% for Opus 4.6. Overlap classification reveals the rewrites are predominantly iterative refinement (63% for 4.5, largest category), not error recovery.

The overlap composition tells a more nuanced story than the headline rewrite rate. When Opus 4.6 does overlap, a larger share is self-correction (31.7% vs 11.5% for 4.5)—meaning 4.6 catches and fixes its own mistakes more explicitly. Opus 4.5’s overlaps are more heavily iterative refinement (63% vs 53%), suggesting gradual adjustment rather than correction. Error recovery rates are comparable (15.7% vs 15.0%).

Interpretation: A lower rewrite rate is consistent with Opus 4.6’s research-first approach—investigating before editing reduces the need for later corrections. However, the distinction between “self-correction” and “iterative refinement” is heuristic-based, and Opus 4.6’s overlap sample is small (n=120), making per-category percentages volatile—the user-directed category at 0.8% represents a single edit.

Edit patterns capture one dimension of how the models work; the next section broadens the lens to overall resource usage and complexity scaling.

Opus 4.6 sessions skew toward higher complexity: fewer trivial tasks (36% vs 47%) and proportionally more moderate tasks (27% vs 21%). This makes raw aggregate comparisons misleading—Opus 4.6 is tackling harder work on average.

 103.4 109.4 B +6%
The exploration–output tradeoff: Tool calls per task and tools per file are the strongest statistical signals in the study (both p<0.000001, Bonferroni). Yet Opus 4.6 produces only 6% more lines of code per task despite 57% more tool calls. The extra activity is predominantly read-only research (74% Explore subagents, §4), not proportional output growth. An alternative reading: 4.6 is simply less efficient, doing more work for similar results. The subagent composition data from §4 supports the research interpretation, but the distinction matters.
Significance: Tool calls/task (p<0.000001, d=−0.29) and tools/file (p<0.000001, d=−0.10) survive Bonferroni correction. The d=−0.10 for tools/file is negligible in practical terms despite statistical significance, an artifact of large sample size. The tool call averages in the table above (10.4 vs 16.3) include subagent calls; the stat test was run on per-task attributed calls (mean 8.8 vs 13.4), which show the same directional effect.

Cross-Cut Detail

Tool calls and tools/file are classified under the “behavior” theme in the cross-cut analysis. Their per-complexity, per-task-type, and per-iteration breakdowns appear in §4’s cross-cut detail (Behavioral Findings). Key results: the tool-call gap is largest for significantly-iterated tasks (d=0.54) and trivial complexity (d=0.31), both Bonferroni-significant.

The preceding sections examined behavioral, quality, and resource dimensions. The next section examines temporal patterns—how performance unfolds within and across sessions.

8. Session Dynamics

Median Task Duration

5-min idle threshold

Task duration survives Bonferroni correction (p=0.000001), though the effect size is negligible (d=0.005)—a case of statistical significance without practical significance, driven by sample size. Opus 4.6 takes longer per task (median 129.6s vs 94.0s from timing analysis). The explore phase runs 2.2× longer at median (68.7s vs 31.3s). Effort distribution shows 4.6 allocates more tool calls to research (35.1% vs 28.3%) and fewer to implementation (17.5% vs 27.0%). Active-time cost is $25.09/hour for 4.6 vs $20.96/hour for 4.5 (5-min idle threshold).

Context Compaction

Context-window compaction occurs in 10.1% of 4.5 sessions (33/327) and 12.5% of 4.6 sessions (17/136). Pre/post comparisons show improvement after compaction, but a position-adjusted control group—splitting non-compacting sessions at the median compaction position to isolate position effects—reveals the effect is driven by session position, not compaction itself (position-adjusted effect: −0.13 for 4.5, −0.23 for 4.6). Compaction appears to preserve rather than degrade performance.

Opus 4.5Opus 4.6
MetricCompacting ΔControl ΔNet effectCompacting ΔControl ΔNet effect

Satisfaction rate +5.8pp +6.1pp −0.4pp +4.8pp +11.1pp −6.3pp

Position-adjusted effect: The negative values indicate compaction preserves rather than degrades performance relative to where it occurs in the session.

Cross-Cut Detail

Duration is classified under the “behavior” theme in the cross-cut analysis. Per-task-type and per-iteration breakdowns appear in §4’s cross-cut detail (Behavioral Findings). Key results: the duration gap is largest for significantly-iterated tasks (median 98.9s vs 42.2s) and investigation tasks (median 100.7s vs 43.3s), both Bonferroni-significant. Effect sizes are negligible (d<0.1) despite significance—driven by sample size, not practical magnitude.

Session dynamics reveal a temporal dimension to the behavioral differences. The next section synthesizes all dimensions into overall model profiles.

9. Model Profiles

Not routing recommendations: These profiles summarize observed behavioral patterns from a single user’s workflow. They describe tendencies in this dataset, not inherent model properties. Different users, tasks, or evaluation periods could produce different profiles.
Opus 4.5 — Observed Pattern

Observed approach: Tends to act first and adjust as needed. Jumps to implementation with minimal upfront research.

Thinking: Thinks on 75% of tasks but shallowly (2,635 avg chars). Over-thinks trivial tasks (§3).

Subagents: 47% Explore, 37% general-purpose (implementation workers). Primarily autonomous (54%).

Planning: Rarely uses planning mode (1.7%). Distributes research evenly through the task (§4).

Observed strengths: Lower tool overhead (mean 8.8 calls/task). 28–35% cheaper at trivial-simple (§2). Stable performance across session lengths (§8).

Observed weaknesses: Higher rewrite rate (16.6%, §6). Higher failure rate (13.2% vs 8.5%, §5).

Opus 4.6 — Observed Pattern

Observed approach: Tends to research first, then implement. Front-loads investigation before touching files.

Thinking: Thinks on 58% of tasks but deeply (4,175 avg chars). Better calibrated—skips thinking on trivial, engages on complex (§3).

Subagents: 74% Explore (read-only research), 15% general-purpose. More autonomous (84%).

Planning: Uses planning mode on 13.9% of tasks (82 of 591). 51% at complex, 72% at major (§4).

Observed strengths: Lower rewrite rate (10.3%, §6). Lower failure rate (8.5%, §5). Lower cost at trivial–moderate (§2).

Observed weaknesses: 53% more tool calls per task (§7). 7% more expensive overall. Costlier at major complexity (n=18, §2).

Observed Patterns by Task Type

Task TypeObserved PatternEvidence & Caveats
Trivial / simple tasksSimilar completion rates4.6 appears 28–35% cheaper (§2); n=808/213 and 345/129
Complex / major tasks4.6 showed higher alignmentn=74+18 for 4.6 vs 190+19 for 4.5; confounded by project differences
Refactoring4.6 produced 2.7× output tokens7,908 vs 2,936 avg output (§2); lower rewrite rate (§6)
Investigation / research4.6 used more Explore agents74% read-only subagents (§4); 2.2× longer explore phase (§8)
Long sessions (9+ tasks)Both show some degradationSmall sample for late-session tasks; 4.6 may degrade faster
Parallel execution4.6 backgrounded more tasks4.5 spawned more agents but ran them sequentially

Data Cleaning Methodology

Task-level data cleaning applied four exclusion rules and four informational flags to canonical tasks before analysis. Exclusions remove tasks that do not represent genuine user-model interactions; flags annotate tasks with contextual metadata without removing them.

Exclusion Rules

RuleDescriptionOpus 4.5Opus 4.6
slash_commandTask prompt is a slash command (/command) or <command-name> tag — these invoke built-in features, not model reasoning——
system_continuationAutomatic continuations triggered by the system (e.g., context compaction boundaries, session resumptions) rather than deliberate user prompts——
empty_continuationBare acknowledgement prompts ("continue", "ok", "yes") with zero tool calls and <5s duration — the model produced no meaningful work——
no_response_interruptTasks where the model produced zero output (0 tool calls, 0 duration) before the session ended, typically user cancellations——

Informational Flags

These flags are preserved on included tasks for subgroup analysis but do not trigger exclusion:

  • meta — Task occurred within a meta-analysis session (e.g., this report's own development), where the model analyzed its own output
  • no_project — No project directory was associated with the session
  • interrupted — User interrupted the model mid-response (based on session end pattern)
  • post_compaction — Task occurred after a context compaction event in the same session, potentially with degraded context

Project Overlap & Sensitivity Analysis

A potential confound arises from unequal project coverage between models. To quantify this, a sensitivity analysis compares all statistical tests on the full dataset against a restricted subset containing only tasks from projects where both models were active. If results agree across both analyses, the project confound is unlikely to explain observed differences.

Each Claude Code session was segmented into tasks based on user-message boundaries and topic shifts. An LLM annotator classified each task for complexity, type, sentiment, completion status, and alignment score (1–5 scale). Behavioral metrics—subagent usage, planning, parallelization—were extracted from tool-call logs.

Cross-Cut Dimensions

All 529 statistical tests are run both at the overall level and stratified across three cross-cut dimensions. Each section’s “Cross-Cut Detail” expansion shows how its metrics behave under each slice.

DimensionLevelsMethod
Complexity trivial (≤3 tools, ≤1 file, ≤20 lines), simple (≤10, ≤3, ≤100), moderate (≤30, ≤10, ≤500), complex (≤80, ≤25, ≤2000), major (above all thresholds) Metric thresholds on tool calls, files touched, and lines changed. Lowest matching tier wins. Keyword heuristics as tiebreaker.
Task type investigation, bugfix, feature, greenfield, refactor, sysadmin, docs, continuation, port LLM-classified (Haiku) from user prompt, tool usage, and work summary. Regex pattern matching provides initial signal; LLM classification overrides at medium/high confidence, resolving previously “unknown” tasks (32.6% of dataset). Eval: 100% unknown resolution, LLM agrees with regex on 55% of classified tasks (LLM typically more accurate on context-dependent prompts).
Iteration one_shot (no back-and-forth), minor (small corrections), significant (multiple rework cycles) LLM-classified from the user’s next message after task completion, informed by edit signal heuristics (self-corrections, rewrite rate).
Minimum sample sizes: Cross-cut cells with fewer than 5–10 observations (depending on test type) are excluded from statistical testing. This primarily affects the “major” complexity tier (n=19/18) and rare task types.

Edit timeline analysis tracked 4,799 Edit/Write tool calls across all sessions, building per-file content ownership maps to detect when a later edit’s old_string overlaps with an earlier edit’s new_string. Overlaps are detected via three tiers (exact match, containment at ≥30% ratio, and Jaccard line overlap) and classified by context (self-correction, error recovery, user-directed, iterative refinement). Edit metrics were joined with task classifications to compute complexity-binned accuracy rates (93% and 88% coverage for the two models).

Compaction analysis found 79 compact_boundary system messages across 50 compacting sessions, extracting trigger type, pre-compaction token count, and position. Outcome impact was measured by splitting tasks into pre/post groups at the first compaction timestamp, with a control group of non-compacting sessions split at the median compaction position to isolate position effects.

Statistical testing: 529 tests were conducted: chi-square (categorical), Mann-Whitney U (continuous), proportion tests (rates). Bonferroni correction was chosen over less conservative alternatives (e.g., Benjamini-Hochberg FDR) to minimize false positives given the observational design; the tradeoff is higher false-negative risk. Corrected threshold: p<0.0000945. Across all 529 tests (overall and per-complexity strata), 93 findings survive Bonferroni and 169 survive FDR correction. At the overall level, seven survive Bonferroni: alignment score (p=0.000001), duration (p=0.000001, though d=0.005—negligible practical effect), tool calls/task (p<0.000001, d=−0.29), tools/file (p<0.000001, d=−0.10), and three categorical distributions (task completion, communication quality, autonomy level). All three chi-square survivors have low-expected-cell-count warnings, which may inflate test statistics. Significance notes appear inline in each section.

To validate robustness, all overall-level tests were re-run on a restricted dataset excluding overlapping projects. This tests whether findings depend on specific project mix or are stable across the data.

Development Process

This analysis was developed iteratively. Several approaches were tried and abandoned when they proved unreliable:

Automated dissatisfaction detection (abandoned as primary signal): Initial LLM-based sentiment classification flagged 7–9% dissatisfaction for both models. LLM-agent audit of all 59 flagged cases revealed 73–93% false positive rates—the classifiers were fooled by task-coordination language (e.g., “fix” in subagent prompts). This approach was replaced by edit timeline analysis, which detects self-corrections mechanistically rather than through sentiment proxies.

LLM quality judgement (dropped): An LLM judge was asked to compare code quality between models. The results were unreliable—the judge lacked sufficient context to evaluate whether code met domain requirements, and produced confident but ungrounded assessments. This section was removed entirely rather than presented with caveats.

Refactoring routing recommendation (revised): Early signals suggested Opus 4.5 was better for refactoring, based on four false-positive dissatisfaction flags and small sample sizes. Sentiment detection and git retention both proved unreliable. Edit timeline analysis provided a more direct mechanistic signal: tracking every edit across all sessions revealed Opus 4.5 with a 16.6% rewrite rate vs 10.3% for Opus 4.6 (now 246 editing tasks, 120 overlapping edits).

Limitations

LLM-in-the-loop analysis: All task classification, sentiment analysis, and alignment scoring was performed by LLM agents (Claude Haiku and Sonnet). This creates a circularity concern: Claude models are classifying Claude model outputs. No formal inter-rater reliability was computed. Human spot-checks validated flagged cases, but systematic bias between models (e.g., if the classifier is more generous toward outputs that resemble its own style) cannot be ruled out. All three overall chi-square Bonferroni survivors and the alignment score depend on LLM-generated categories.

Single user: All data comes from one developer’s workflow. Results may not generalize to other users, codebases, or task distributions.

Temporal confound: Opus 4.5 spans 2 months; Opus 4.6 spans 8 days. A productive week, a particular project focus, or simply the novelty of a new model could color all 591 Opus 4.6 tasks simultaneously. The null hypothesis—that all observed differences reflect the user’s changing work patterns rather than model capabilities—cannot be rejected by this design.

Observational, not experimental: Tasks were not randomly assigned to models. Opus 4.6 was used later chronologically and on different (often harder) tasks, confounding model effects with task effects.

Complexity confound: Opus 4.6’s different complexity mix (42% moderate-and-above vs 33% for Opus 4.5) inflates its resource usage metrics and may suppress its satisfaction scores. Complexity-stratified comparisons would isolate model effects from mix effects but are not yet in the pipeline.

Platform evolution: The Claude Code SDK evolved between December 2025 and February 2026. Changes to system prompts, available tools, or subagent defaults could contribute to behavioral differences attributed to the models.

Sample asymmetry: The 2.9:1 ratio (1,729 vs 591 tasks) means Opus 4.5 estimates have narrower confidence intervals. Effect sizes for Opus 4.6 are less precise.

User learning effect: The user may have learned to use Claude Code more effectively over time, benefiting whichever model came second in the chronological sequence.

Claude Code Early Access Program · Single-user exploratory case study · February 2026
